com.avaya.csta.terminal

Interface TerminalServices

  • Deprecated. 
    As of release 3.1, replaced by RegistrationServices

    public interface TerminalServices
    A set of services that allows applications to take control of Communication Manager phones/extensions and their media streams through a registration process. These services are an extension to the ECMA-269 CSTA specification. Registering a device gives the application either exclusive control or shared control of a DCP or IP hardphone or extension that is administered for softphone access on Communication Manager. Exclusive control mode gives all control of the device to the application including the media stream. In shared control mode the phone and the application share control. (see Supported Telephone Configurations for more information). Unregistering a device gives up control of the device. Register a device before acting upon it with any of the API services and then unregister it when the application is through with it.

    In the registration request, you can set the media parameters and even request control of the media stream. This is done by setting the local media information in the registration request. After registration, we recommend that your application wait 1 second before making a call. This allows Communication Manager to be ready for the call.

    Prerequisites Before using TerminalServices, do the following:

    1. Get access to TerminalServices through the ServiceProvider. For example: 
       TerminalServices termSvcs =
   (TerminalServices)servProv.getService(com.avaya.csta.terminal.TerminalServices.class.getName());
    2. Get a device ID for the phone or extension you wish to gain shared or exclusive control of by using DeviceServices. For example: 
       // Put a GetDeviceID request together based on switch and extension.
 GetDeviceId devIDReq = new GetDeviceId();
 devIDReq.setSwitchName(switchName);
 devIDReq.setExtension(extension);

 // Use DeviceServices to request a device ID
 DeviceServices devSvcs =
  (DeviceServices)servProv.getService(com.avaya.csta.device.DeviceServices.class.getName())
 GetDeviceIdResponse devIDResp = devSvcs.getDeviceID(devIDReq);
 DeviceID deviceID = devIDResp.getDevice();
    3. Add the desired listeners. Monitor registration progress by implementing TerminalListener and adding your listener implementation using MonitoringServices.addTerminalListener. Monitor for media events on the device by implementing MediaControlListener and adding your listener implementation using MonitoringServices.addMediaControlListener. MediaControlListener will receive media events regardless of whether the media is controlled by the connector server or your application. You may wish to ignore media events if the media is controlled by the connector server. Media Events are not available in shared control mode.

    Clean Up When you are finished using the device, do the following:

    1. Unregister the device using the TerminalServices.unregisterDevice method.
    2. Remove any listeners that were added for that device using MonitoringServices.removeTerminalListener and MonitoringServices.removeMediaControlListener.
    3. Release the device ID, using DeviceServices.
    Version:
    $Revision: 1.9 $
    Author:
    AVAYA, Inc.

    • Field Detail

      • IDLE

        static final RegistrationState IDLE
        Deprecated. 
        Constants that may be used to compare against the RegistrationState object of the GetRegistrationStateResponse. GetRegistrationStateResponse and its callback methods are defined in GetRegistrationStateResponse. The constants are used to compare against this GetRegistrationStateResponse parameter:
        • RegistrationState- The registration state for the requested device ID. Use GetRegistrationStateResponse.getRegistrationState() to extract the RegistrationState from the response object.

        Deprecated. 

    • Method Detail

      • registerDevice

        RegisterDeviceResponse registerDevice(RegisterDevice request)
                               throws CstaException
        Deprecated. as of 3.1, replaced by RegistrationServices.registerTerminal
        Registers a specific device with Communication Manager in order to gain shared control or exclusive control over the phone or extension. See the RegisterDevice request for more information. The types of DCP and IP phones and extensions that can be controlled are described in Supported Telephone Configurations.

        Your code to setup the RegisterDevice request may look like this if you want shared control: 

           RegisterDevice regReq = new RegisterDevice();
   regReq.setDevice(id);
   LoginInfo login = new LoginInfo();
   login.setPassword(password);
   login.setSharedControl(new Boolean(true));
   regRequest.setLoginInfo(login);
        To register in exclusive mode, set shared control mode to false as shown below or let it default to false: 
           login.setSharedControl(new Boolean(false));
        If you also want to change the preferred codecs, preferred encryption type and/or packet size, then you will add: 
           MediaInfo localMediaInfo = new MediaInfo();
   
   String [] codecs = new String [2];
   codecs [0] = MediaConstants.G729;   // first choice
   codecs [1] = MediaConstants.G729A;  // second choice
   localMediaInfo.setCodecs (codecs);
   
   String [] encryption = new String [2];
   encryption [0] = MediaConstants.AES;          // first choice
   encryption [1] = MediaConstants.NOENCRYPTION; // second choice
   localMediaInfo.setEncryption (encryption);
   
   localmediaInfo.setPacketSize (new Integer (20));
   regReq.setLocalMediaInfo(localMediaInfo);
        If you want to have the media stream terminate at the application or some other application-specified IP address, then you will also insert code to set the RTP/RTCP address, like this: 
         //Set RTP address to an even address
 InetAddress inetAddress = InetAddress.getAllByName("pcname.yourcompany.com");
 IPAddress ipAddress = new IPAddress();
 ipAddress.setAddress(inetAddress.getAddress());
 ipAddress.setPort(9000);
 localMediaInfo.setRtpAddress(ipAddress);

 //Set RTCP address to next odd address
 ipAddress.setPort(9001);
 localMediaInfo.setRtcpAddress(ipAddress);
        After the RegisterDevice request is setup, send the request with code like this: 
           RegisterDeviceResponse regResp = termSvcs.registerDevice (regReq);

        If you have added one or more TerminalListeners, then the listener's callback methods are called as registration progresses. If there is a problem with the request, an exception is thrown.

        Registration is an asynchronous process and can take a relatively long time. For this reason, the result of a registration attempt is not indicated by the response to this method. Rather the registration result is indicated by an event sent to the TerminalListeners that have been added. To avoid potential timing problems, a TerminalListener should be added prior to calling the registerDevice method. If a listener is added after the registerDevice method is called, the listener may or may not receive the appropriate event (the event may occur before the listener is added).

        The TerminalListener events that may be caused by a RegisterDevice request include:

        • RegisteredEvent
        • RegisterFailedEvent
        If your application will control the media stream, then it will also need to monitor the media events. The MediaControlListener events that may be caused by a RegisterDevice request include:
        • MediaStartEvent
        • MediaStopEvent
        Parameters:
        request - the RegisterDevice request that contains the device ID, the device's password and other optional parameters to register the device.
        Returns:
        the RegisterDeviceResponse when TerminalServices has accepted the request, the request appears valid, and the request is being processed. It provides no useful information.
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - if there is no station associated with the DeviceID or the format of DeviceID is not correct
        InvalidActiveDeviceStateException - if the station is in the process of registering or unregistering
        InvalidParameterValueException - if the password is NULL or the request is NULL or there is an invalid codec or invalid encryption specified
        InvalidDeviceStateException - if the device is already registered
        ParameterNotSupportedException - if unsupported parameters are used
        OperationException - if there is an operation error such as a socket IO exception error.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the request parameter is null
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • unregisterDevice

        UnregisterDeviceResponse unregisterDevice(UnregisterDevice request)
                                   throws CstaException
        Deprecated. as of 3.1, replaced by RegistrationServices.unregisterTerminal
        Unregisters the specified device from Communication Manager in order to give up control of the device. Be sure to unregister devices when they are no longer needed. See the UnregisterDevice request for more information. Warning: If you fail to unregister the device, Communication Manager will keep the device registered to the connector server indefinitely.
        Parameters:
        request - the UnregisterDevice request that contains the DeviceID and other optional parameters required to unregister the device.
        Returns:
        the UnregisterDeviceResponse when TerminalServices has accepted the request, the request appears valid, and the request is being processed.
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - if there is no station associated with the device ID specified.
        InvalidDeviceStateException - if the device is in the wrong state.
        InvalidParameterValueException - if the request is NULL.
        OperationException - if there is an operation error such as a socket IO exception error
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • getRegistrationState

        GetRegistrationStateResponse getRegistrationState(GetRegistrationState request)
                                           throws CstaException
        Deprecated. as of 3.1, replaced by RegistrationServices.getRegistrationState
        Returns the registration state for the requested device. See the GetRegistrationState request for more information.
        Parameters:
        request - the GetRegistrationState request that contains the DeviceID for which to get the registration state.
        Returns:
        the GetRegistrationStateResponse containing the RegistrationState indicating the registration state for the requested DeviceID
        Throws:
        InvalidDeviceIDException - if there is no station associated with the device ID specified.
        InvalidParameterValueException - if the request is NULL.
        OperationException - if there is an operation error such as a socket IO exception error
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • addTerminalListener

        void addTerminalListener(DeviceID device,
                         TerminalListener listener)
                  throws CstaException
        Deprecated. Use MonitoringServices.addTerminalistener instead.
        Adds a TerminalListener for receiving registration events for a specific device. If multiple listeners are added, all listeners will be notified of events. For more information about using listeners see Using Listeners in the Device, Media & Call Control (DMCC) API.

        Registration events include:

        • RegisteredEvent
        • RegisterFailedEvent
        • UnregisterEvent

        When your application no longer wants to be notified of registration events for a device, use the removeTerminalListener for each listener that was added.

        Parameters:
        device - the DeviceID to register the listener for
        listener - the TerminalListener implementation to add
        Throws:
        OperationException - if there is no station associated with the DeviceID. Check DeviceID or create DeviceID first.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the listener parameter is null
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • removeTerminalListener

        void removeTerminalListener(DeviceID device,
                            TerminalListener listener)
                     throws CstaException
        Deprecated. Use MonitoringServices.removeTerminalListener instead.
        Removes the specified TerminalListener from receiving device registration events.
        Parameters:
        device - the DeviceID for which this TerminalListener should be removed
        listener - the TerminalListener to remove
        Throws:
        OperationException - if there is no station associated with the DeviceID. Cannot remove listener. Please check the DeviceID.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the listener parameter is null
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • addMediaControlListener

        void addMediaControlListener(DeviceID device,
                             MediaControlListener listener)
                      throws CstaException
        Deprecated. Use MonitoringServices.addMediaControlListener instead.
        Adds a MediaControlListener for receiving media control events for a specific device. Used by applications that wish to be notified of media events - usually these are applications that are controlling the media stream.

        If multiple listeners are added, all listeners will be notified of events. For more information about using listeners see Using Listeners in the Device, Media & Call Control (DMCC) API.

        Media control events include:

        • MediaStartEvent
        • MediaStopEvent
        Use these events in conjunction with PhysicalDeviceListener's LampModeEvent to determine when media is connected, been shuffled to a different far-end IP address, or has been disconnected. See MediaControlListener for more information about handling media events.
        Parameters:
        device - the DeviceID to register the listener for
        listener - the MediaControlListener to add
        Throws:
        OperationException - if there is no station associated with the DeviceID
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the listener parameter is null
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • removeMediaControlListener

        void removeMediaControlListener(DeviceID device,
                                MediaControlListener listener)
                         throws CstaException
        Deprecated. Use MonitoringServices.removeMediaControlListener instead.
        Removes the specified MediaControlListener from receiving media control events for the specified device.
        Parameters:
        device - the DeviceID whose listener is being removed
        listener - the MediaControlListener to remove
        Throws:
        OperationException - if there is no station associated with the DeviceID
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the listener parameter is null
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs
